gw.api.database

Class DBFunction

  • java.lang.Object
    • gw.api.database.DBFunction
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IQueryColumn

    public class DBFunction
extends Object
implements IQueryColumn
    A set of static methods used to wrap a column in a SQL function

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      IType FeatureType
      the feature type of the underlying property for this function. I.e. Max(TestA.A) will return Integer if TestA.A is an integer.
      String Name
      IEntityType OwnersType
      com.guidewire.commons.system.database.SQLFunction SQLFunction

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      static DBFunction Avg(ColumnRef column)
      static DBFunction Avg(IEntityType type, String propertyName)
      static BigDecimal Avg(T protoValue)
      static BigDecimal Avg(Number[] protoValue)
      static DBFunction Constant(Object value)
      Returns a constant wrapped so that it can be used in SQL whenever you want a literal parameter.

      This is typically used to compare a constant value against something in SQL. This version automatically utilizes datatype based on the type of the value. For example:

      var q = new Query(TestE) var aTable = q.join(TestA, "E") q.having().compare(DBFunction.Constant(false), Equals, DBFunction.Count( aTable.getColumnRef( "A" ) ))
      static DBFunction Constant(String value)
      Returns a constant wrapped so that it can be used in SQL whenever you want a literal parameter.

      This is typically used to compare a constant value against something in SQL. For example:

      var q = Query.make(Person) q.compareIgnoreCase("LastName", Equals, DBFunction.Constant("Smith"))
      static DBFunction Constant(IDataType dataType, Object value)
      Returns a constant wrapped so that it can be used in SQL whenever you want a literal parameter.

      This is typically used to compare a constant value against something in SQL. This version allows for an arbitrary datatype. For example:

      var q = new Query(TestE) var aTable = q.join(TestA, "E") q.having().compare(DBFunction.Constant(DataTypes.bit(), false), Equals, DBFunction.Count( aTable.getColumnRef( "A" ) ))
      static DBFunction Constant(Number value)
      Returns a constant wrapped so that it can be used in SQL whenever you want a literal parameter.

      This can be used to compare a constant value against something in SQL in a having clause. For example:

      var q = new Query(TestE) var aTable = q.join(TestA, "E") q.having().compare(DBFunction.Constant(2), Equals, DBFunction.Count( aTable.getColumnRef( "A" ) ))
      static DBFunction Count(ColumnRef column)
      static DBFunction Count(IEntityType type, String propertyName)
      static Integer Count(Object protoValue)
      static Integer Count(Object[] protoValue)
      static DBFunction DateDiff(DateDiffPart dateDiffPart, ColumnRef startDate, ColumnRef endDate)
      static DBFunction DateFromTimestamp(ColumnRef timestamp)
      static DBFunction DatePart(DatePart datePart, ColumnRef date)
      static DBFunction Distance(Query<T> query, String beanPath)
      static DBFunction Expr(Object[] expr)
      Returns a function defined by the given expression. The expression is a list containing either {@link java.lang.CharSequence}s or {@link ColumnRef}s. The objects in the list will be concatenated together to form a SQL expression. For example, the following code creates a function which computes the sum of two columns. ColumnRef column1 = ... ColumnRef column2 = ... DBFunction columnSum = DBFunction.Expr({column1, " + ", column2}) Note that single quotes are stripped. To include a single quote in the pattern string use two single quotes.

      The user is advised to prefer the use of a {@link ColumnRef} for a column over a {@link java.lang.CharSequence} because a {@link ColumnRef} encapsulates the table alias.
      static DBFunction Max(ColumnRef column)
      static DBFunction Max(IEntityType type, String propertyName)

      • Constant

        DBFunction Constant(Object value)
        Returns a constant wrapped so that it can be used in SQL whenever you want a literal parameter.

        This is typically used to compare a constant value against something in SQL. This version automatically utilizes datatype based on the type of the value. For example:

        var q = new Query(TestE) var aTable = q.join(TestA, "E") q.having().compare(DBFunction.Constant(false), Equals, DBFunction.Count( aTable.getColumnRef( "A" ) ))

        Parameters:
        value - the constant value to search on
        Returns:
        the constant value

      • Constant

        DBFunction Constant(String value)
        Returns a constant wrapped so that it can be used in SQL whenever you want a literal parameter.

        This is typically used to compare a constant value against something in SQL. For example:

        var q = Query.make(Person) q.compareIgnoreCase("LastName", Equals, DBFunction.Constant("Smith"))

        Parameters:
        value - the constant value to search on
        Returns:
        the constant value

      • Constant

        DBFunction Constant(IDataType dataType,
                  Object value)
        Returns a constant wrapped so that it can be used in SQL whenever you want a literal parameter.

        This is typically used to compare a constant value against something in SQL. This version allows for an arbitrary datatype. For example:

        var q = new Query(TestE) var aTable = q.join(TestA, "E") q.having().compare(DBFunction.Constant(DataTypes.bit(), false), Equals, DBFunction.Count( aTable.getColumnRef( "A" ) ))

        Parameters:
        dataType - the datatype of the constant value
        value - the constant value to search on
        Returns:
        the constant value

      • Constant

        DBFunction Constant(Number value)
        Returns a constant wrapped so that it can be used in SQL whenever you want a literal parameter.

        This can be used to compare a constant value against something in SQL in a having clause. For example:

        var q = new Query(TestE) var aTable = q.join(TestA, "E") q.having().compare(DBFunction.Constant(2), Equals, DBFunction.Count( aTable.getColumnRef( "A" ) ))

        Parameters:
        value - the constant value to search on
        Returns:
        the constant value

      • DateDiff

        DBFunction DateDiff(DateDiffPart dateDiffPart,
                  ColumnRef startDate,
                  ColumnRef endDate)
        Parameters:
        dateDiffPart - Unit of measure for date difference
        startDate - Starting date time
        endDate - Ending date time
        Returns:
        a function that computes the difference between two datetime columns. The answer is returned in a unit of measure determined by the first argument. Note that database difference functions do not adjust for daylight savings time. For example, if you ask for the number of hours between noon on 11/5/11 and noon on 11/6/11, you will get 24 back, even though 25 hours has elapsed.

      • DateFromTimestamp

        DBFunction DateFromTimestamp(ColumnRef timestamp)
        Parameters:
        timestamp - Timestamp to be trimmed to a date
        Returns:
        a function taht extracts just the date from the given timestamp

      • DatePart

        DBFunction DatePart(DatePart datePart,
                  ColumnRef date)
        Parameters:
        datePart - Part of date to be extracted
        date - Date being processed
        Returns:
        a function that extracts the specified date part from the date.

      • Distance

        DBFunction Distance(Query<T> query,
                  String beanPath)
        Parameters:
        query - The query containing the spatial search restriction
        beanPath -
        Returns:
        the distance function. Only valid if the query has a proximity search, otherwise fails in unpredictable ways.

      • Expr

        DBFunction Expr(Object[] expr)
        Returns a function defined by the given expression. The expression is a list containing either {@link java.lang.CharSequence}s or {@link ColumnRef}s. The objects in the list will be concatenated together to form a SQL expression. For example, the following code creates a function which computes the sum of two columns. ColumnRef column1 = ... ColumnRef column2 = ... DBFunction columnSum = DBFunction.Expr({column1, " + ", column2}) Note that single quotes are stripped. To include a single quote in the pattern string use two single quotes.

        The user is advised to prefer the use of a {@link ColumnRef} for a column over a {@link java.lang.CharSequence} because a {@link ColumnRef} encapsulates the table alias.

        Parameters:
        expr - objects in the list will be concatenated together to form a SQL expression.
        Returns:
        a function defined by the given expression
